title: Tesla to Rent Solar Panels to Homeowners
summary: Shift in business model is made to jump-start residential installations. Tesla Inc., better known for making electric cars, is once again offering to rent solar panels to homeowners.

title: Trump Calls for a Big Fed Rate Cut, Again Criticizes Powell
summary: President says Jerome Powell has 'horrendous lack of vision,' says big reduction would improve economy. WASHINGTON-President Trump on Monday called for the Federal Reserve to sharply cut interest rates and again criticized the central bank's chairman for a "horrendous lack of vision," while reiterating his belief that the U.S. economy is strong.

title: Pakistan Extends Powerful Army Chief's Term
summary: Prime Minister Imran Khan cites regional security concerns in giving Gen. ISLAMABAD-Pakistan's army chief will serve another three years as the country deals with the Afghanistan peace process and tension with India.

title: New York City Union Uses Its Size to Leverage Improved Maternity Care
summary: Expectant mothers in the health fund are largely low-wage workers and women of color, its director says. In a bid to provide better health outcomes for pregnant women and reduce health care costs, one of New York City's largest unions is pushing local hospital systems to create specialty maternity-care networks.

title: Final Bows Boost Broadway Ticket Sales
summary: As shows near the end of their runs, ad campaigns can spark a box-office rush. A number of shows have closed on Broadway this month. But they are not ending their runs without a burst of box-office glory.

title: McKinsey Dodges Lawsuit Targeting Its Bankruptcy Disclosures
summary: Turnaround executive's racketeering lawsuit against McKinsey has no legal basis, according to a federal judge's ruling. A federal judge dismissed a racketeering lawsuit brought against McKinsey & Co. by turnaround industry veteran Jay Alix, who claimed the consulting firm profited by failing to disclose conflicts of interest in bankruptcy cases.

title: Trump Is Losing the Trade War With China
summary: The markets doubt tariffs will bring about any major concessions. The U.S. needs a multilateral approach.. President Trump's China strategy is failing. His tougher approach has yielded no meaningful Chinese concessions but is increasingly damaging the U.S. economy. Today China is more integrated with the rest of the world while the U.S. is more isolated. To combat China's unfair, statist economic practices effectively, the U.S. must change its approach, enlisting allies and international institutions to advance a more focused set of demands.

title: The Fed Has Too Much to Do
summary: Let private companies run the payments system. The central bank is already overextended.. The Federal Reserve announced earlier this month that it will launch a real-time payment service called "FedNow" sometime in the next five years. The move demonstrates that the independent central bank, already one of the most unaccountable agencies in the federal government, is accumulating too much power. In recent years the Fed has fended off several efforts to determine whether its expenditures-which aren't appropriated by Congress-are consistent with policies that the American people and their representatives want the central bank to pursue.

title: Free-Marketeers Have Taken Social Conservatives for Granted
summary: Capitalists need to make the case that prosperity is crucial for protecting tradition and security.. For many free-market advocates, the recent conservative dalliance with noncapitalist policies has been as stunning as it has been swift. While President Trump's antipathy to free trade was well-known, his and other conservatives' sudden embrace of aggressive antitrust actions was more surprising. Now self-described "national conservative" thinkers are pushing industrial policy-government planning that meddles with economic decision-making to promote favored industries or social outcomes.

title: 'The Twenty-Six Words That Created the Internet' Review: Protecting the Providers
summary: Section 230 protects websites and online service providers from liability for what their users post. Has the time come to rethink it?. Americans are of two minds about the internet: They rely on it and fear it, they immerse themselves in it for hours and deplore its social consequences. Even some tech writers, people who a decade ago gushed about the web's limitless possibilities for connectedness and free expression, now frequently sound like Gollum emoting about the Ring. It's still their precious, but they hates it.

title: A Forbidden Word's Lost Lessons
summary: A professor is under investigation for accurately quoting James Baldwin.. The N-word again-the dangerous taboo. At New York's New School, Prof. Laurie Sheck was teaching a class on the work of the novelist and essayist James Baldwin. She cited the 2016 documentary "I Am Not Your Negro," and pointed out that the title was a bowdlerized version of an actual quote from Baldwin, in which he used the N-word.

title: Apologize, Carrie Lam
summary: A little humility from the Hong Kong and Beijing governments could end this crisis.. Hong Kongers took to the streets again Sunday, some 1.7 million strong. Sunday's march was also meant to highlight their commitment to peaceful protest.

title: Big Business and its 'Stakeholders'
summary: Most of the Business Roundtable commits to "deliver value" to people who don't own any shares.. All but a handful of America's largest public corporations on Monday vaguely agreed to serve "stakeholders," including people with no direct connection to their firms. Leaders of 181 of the 193 member companies of the Business Roundtable promised to "deliver value" to people who don't necessarily own any shares.

title: U.S. Prisons Chief Removed in Wake of Epstein Suicide
summary: FBI, Justice Department's inspector general have launched investigations into the death. The acting chief of the federal Bureau of Prisons has been ousted from his post, Attorney General William Barr said on Monday, continuing the fallout over the suicide of disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein in a New York detention facility that has struggled with staffing shortages and other problems.

title: Warren Apologizes at Native American Forum
summary: Democratic presidential candidate acknowledges 'harm I have caused' at forum. Sen. title: The 'Stakeholder' CEOs
summary: Executives who abandon shareholders won't appease the socialists.. Today's corporate CEO is a politician as much as business leader, and for proof look no further than the statement Monday from the Business Roundtable ostentatiously redefining its mission to serve "stakeholders" in addition to the shareholders who own the company. A close reading shows there's less substance here than meets the media spin, but it's still notable that the CEOs for America's biggest companies feel the need to distance themselves from their owners.

title: Little League Slows the Home Run Revolution
summary: A switch to a 'deader' bat that mimics wood bats has reduced the number of home runs hit at the Little League Baseball World Series. At facilities like New York Empire Baseball in New York, TV screens and iPads surrounding the cage display information about body and ball movement, some of which are picked up by sensors attached to players with black straps.

title: 'Vampire' VC Firms Are Envy of the World
summary: Sen. Elizabeth Warren's proposed bill will be a disruptive factor in the healthy and normal flow of capital out of wasting assets and into job-creating enterprises.. Regarding your editorial "Elizabeth the Vampire Slayer" (Aug. 10): Sen. Elizabeth Warren's bill to stop private-equity firms from killing companies, "The Stop Wall Street Looting Act," demonstrates yet again that she is clueless regarding capitalism. Countries around the world envy and attempt to copy or find substitutes for the disruptive forces of private equity (PE), venture capital and hedge funds in the U.S. American capitalism facilitates relatively rapid redeployment of capital from businesses that are foundering to those that can innovate and grow. The nurturing of capitalism's creative destruction arguably accounts, in large part, for America's explosive growth over the past century. Most other countries hamstring their disruptive forces with top-down controls or with state ownership of obese enterprises that are subsidized or protected from competition.

title: Fed's Rosengren Still Doesn't See Need to Lower Rates
summary: 'There are costs to easing at a time when you don't need to ease,' the Boston Fed president says. With the move, chef-owners Norma Listman and Saqib Keval are expanding their menu and adding a natural wine shop. title: Inside the European Co-working Space That's Coming to Los Angeles
summary: With locations in London and Lisbon, coworking space Second Home arrives in East Hollywood with its anti-clubby policies that aim to cultivate an eclectic mix of tenants. L.A. is one of the most diverse cities in the world," says Second Home co-founder Rohan Silva, "but there are still too many walls-too many barriers between different types of people, communities, industries." These are the walls that he and business partner Sam Aldenton are seeking to break down with the new East Hollywood location of their workspace and cultural venue, which already has locations in London and Lisbon. Unlike Soho House and other members-only clubs, Second Home offers spaces and cultural programming that are open to the public, with the aim of promoting diversity and creativity. In fact, it subsidizes rent for certain smaller community groups and nonprofits, curating an eclectic mix of tenants. Rejecting a corporate aesthetic, Second Home embraces the playful architecture of Spanish firm Selgascano, which has designed nearly all of its locations. (Second Home also recently brought Selgascano's rainbow-hued Serpentine Pavilion structure to L.A.'s La Brea Tar Pits.) Opening in September, Second Home L.A. occupies a 90,000-square-foot campus that's home to a 1963 Paul Williams-designed building as well as Selgascano's 60 yellow-roofed, oval-shaped studios that from the air look like a series of golden droplets. On the grounds, 6,500 new trees and plants are watered by a special retention system that captures rainfall. "[It's] a million miles away from another glass cube," Silva says. secondhome.io
